title: Worden Park Walking Route

images.title: Ann Cook / Bridge over Shaw Brook, Worden Park
images.caption: Bridge over Shaw Brook. This is one of many bridges which cross Shaw Brook as it winds its way through the woods at the southern end of Worden Park.

images.title: Margaret Clough / Spring greenhouse at Worden Hall
images.caption: Spring greenhouse at Worden Hall. It was designated a grade II listed building, but was de-listed in 2017.

images.title: Ann Cook / Hall car park, Worden Park
images.caption: Hall car park. This car park is in the centre of the park, next to the theatre and craft area.

images.title: Ann Cook / Stable Clock
images.caption: Stable Clock. The clock tower overlooks the stable yard, to the rear of where Worden Hall once stood, before it was burnt down in 1941.

images.title: Margaret Clough / Dog wash at the car park at Worden Park
images.caption: Dog wash at the car park.

images.title: Margaret Clough, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cedar of Lebanon tree.

images.title: Ann Cook / Miniature Railway
images.caption: The miniature railway winds through woodland next to the car park in the centre of the park. The station, which can be seen in the rear of the photo, is the home of the Leyland Model Society and, on many weekends when they run their trains, rides are available to the public. This summer [2006] the track is being extended greatly and will eventually run through large areas of the park.

description: This super country park in Leyland is perfect for a peaceful afternoon stroll. The park covers 150 acres and includes formal gardens overlooked by a wonderful conservatory with an accompanying maze. There are also woodlands, a duck pond, a folly, a water cascade, a mininiture railway, the 18th Century domed icehouse and waterside trails along the Shaw Brook which runs through the park. The park is located just half a mile south of Leyland town centre in Lancashire. There's a good sized car park at the site or you could walk from Leyland train station which is about a mile or so north of the site.
